definitions.definition: if somebody/something has a particular tendency, they are likely to behave or act in a particular way
definitions.sensetop: tendency to do somethingtendency for somebody/something to do somethingtendency to/towards something

examples.text: I **have a tendency** to talk too much when I'm nervous.
This material has a tendency to shrink when washed.
There is a tendency for this disease to run in families.
examples.contextForm: tendency for somebody/something to do something

examples.text: She has a strong natural tendency towards caution.
The new model has an unfortunate tendency to break after a few weeks' use.
They needed help for self-harm and suicidal tendencies.
a worrying tendency to blame victims for being assaulted
our natural human tendency to group all the things we don't like together
The natural tendency is to try harder when there are problems with a project.
We have a tendency to blame ourselves when things go wrong.
The training courses aim to reduce the tendency for young people to leave the industry.
They have a tendency towards over-optimism.

definitions.definition: a new custom that is starting to develop
definitions.sensetop: tendency (for somebody/something) (to do something)tendency to/towards something

examples.text: There's a growing tendency for women to marry later.
Industry showed a tendency towards increasingly centralized administration.
There is a growing tendency among employers to hire casual staff.
There is a tendency for farm sizes to increase.

definitions.definition: a group within a larger political group, whose views are more extreme than those of the rest of the group

examples.text: a growing separatist tendency within the Anglo-Irish community

wordOrigin: early 17th cent.: from medieval Latin tendentia, from tendere ‘to stretch’.
